Question_1.Context: Based on the study's findings on the impact of block copolymers on polymer blend nanocomposites, particularly in relation to electrical conductivity.
Question_1.Question: What effect did the addition of SEBS triblock copolymer have on the electrical conductivity of the PP/PS 80:20 blend nanocomposite?
Question_1.D: Conductivity remained the same as the uncompatibilized blend
Question_1.Source: we achieved better PS/MWCNT domain interconnectivity in the PP/PS 80:20 blend system that led to a significant increase in conductivity (four orders of magnitude increase).

Question_2.Context: In the study, what was the observed trend in electrical conductivity for the PP/PS 50:50 blend nanocomposite with the addition of block copolymers?
Question_2.Question: How did the electrical conductivity change with the addition of SEBS triblock copolymer at 3 vol% concentration in the PP/PS 50:50 blend nanocomposite?
Question_2.D: Conductivity remained the same as the uncompatibilized blend
Question_2.Source: we achieved 4 orders of magnitude increase in electrical conductivity with 3% triblock SEBS copolymer.

Question_3.Context: Regarding the impact of block copolymers on rheological properties of polymer blend nanocomposites.
Question_3.Question: What effect did the addition of SEBS triblock copolymer have on the storage modulus of the PP/PS 80:20 blend nanocomposite?
Question_3.B: No significant change in storage modulus
Question_3.D: Storage modulus remained the same as the uncompatibilized blend
Question_3.Source: we observed that higher concentration of 10 vol% of diblock copolymer, gave higher modulus at low strain and same also applies for the loss modulus.

Question_4.Context: Considering the morphology evolution in the PP/PS 20:80 blend nanocomposite with the addition of block copolymers.
Question_4.Question: What was the initial effect on electrical conductivity at lower copolymer concentrations in the PP/PS 20:80 blend nanocomposite?
Question_4.D: Conductivity remained the same as the uncompatibilized blend
Question_4.Source: we saw an initial decrease in the electrical conductivity at low copolymer concentrations (1 vol%)

Question_5.Context: Regarding the impact of block copolymers on the morphology of polymer blend nanocomposites.
Question_5.Question: What was the observed effect of adding diblock SEP copolymer to the PP/PS 50:50 blend nanocomposite?
Question_5.Source: However, upon adding diblock copolymer, we observed a reduced droplet domain size.

Question_6.Context: In relation to the impact of block copolymers on the morphology evolution of polymer blend nanocomposites.
Question_6.Question: What was the morphology observed in the PP/PS 80:20 blend nanocomposite with the addition of SEBS triblock copolymer at 1 vol% concentration?
Question_6.Source: we achieved about two orders of magnitude increase compared to the uncompatibilized blend nanocomposite and a corresponding plateau-like behavior in the low-frequency region.

Question_7.Context: Considering the impact of block copolymers on the morphology of polymer blend nanocomposites.
Question_7.Question: What was the observed effect of adding SEBS triblock copolymer to the PP/PS 50:50 blend nanocomposite?
Question_7.Source: adding triblock copolymer to the blend nanocomposite results in a more co-continuous morphology compared to that obtained by adding the diblock copolymer.

Question_8.Context: Regarding the impact of block copolymers on the electrical conductivity of polymer blend nanocomposites.
Question_8.Question: What was the observed trend in electrical conductivity for the PS/CNT single polymer nanocomposite?
Question_8.Source: The PS/CNT single polymer nanocomposite shows a very high conductivity (just over 10− 2 S/cm) compared to the very low conductivity of PP/CNT (just below 10− 6 S/cm) in the absence of any compatibilizer.

Question_9.Context: In relation to the impact of block copolymers on the electrical conductivity of polymer blend nanocomposites.
Question_9.Question: What was the effect of adding SEBS triblock copolymer at 10 vol% concentration in the PP/PS 20:80 blend nanocomposite?
Question_9.D: Conductivity remained the same as the uncompatibilized blend
Question_9.Source: at 10 vol% SEBS, the conductivity increases, with a value of 1.05*10−1S/cm at 10 vol% SEBS.

Question_10.Context: Considering the impact of block copolymers on the rheological properties of polymer blend nanocomposites.
Question_10.Question: What was the observed effect on the storage modulus of the blend nanocomposites made with SEP diblock copolymer?
Question_10.B: No significant change in storage modulus
Question_10.D: Storage modulus remained the same as the uncompatibilized blend
Question_10.Source: higher concentration of 10 vol% of diblock copolymer, gave higher modulus at low strain and same also applies for the loss modulus.
